values:
Except, I'm not gonna tag!


1. Grab the nearest book.
2. Open the book to page 123.
3. Find the fifth sentence.
4. Post the text of the next 4-7 sentences on your LJ along with these instructions.
5. Don't you dare dig for that "cool" or "intellectual" book in your closet! I know you were thinking about it! Just pick up whatever is closest (unless it's too troublesome to reach and is really heavy. Then go back to step 1).
6. Tag five people.

His attention was riveted totally on Silk's flickering fingers.
"Don't shout," Silk instructed as Garion practiced.
"Shout?" Garion asked, Puzzled.
"Keep your gestures small. Don't exaggerate them. The idea is to make the whole business inconspicuous."

Pawn of Prophecy - Book One of The Belgariad by David Eddings

So let me get this straight--Larry King is getting his 8th divorce, Elizabeth Taylor is possibly getting married for a 9th time, Britney Spears had a 55 hour marriage. Jesse James and Tiger Woods are screwing EVERYTHING--yet the idea of same-sex marriage is going to destroy the institution of marriage??

Really?? REALLY??

Repost to your page if you agree.

::tsk:: Haven't they ever watched Pleasantville?

David and I moved into this house four years ago, on the day of my nana's funeral. It wasn't quite ready to be inhabited but once we'd tidied up after the wake (which had been intended as her 90th birthday party), we felt the need to move forward and celebrate being alive, even though we were sad that she hadn't seen the house and didn't get to see us settled. Nana wasn't a social person and was happy in her own surroundings, but she loved to hear about what we'd done and where we'd been and took delight in facilitating our fun, often, providing us with the cash so that we could live a little and share the experience with her later.

It's strange that I hadn't really embraced the concept of celebration until that day. It was a word, word  written on greeting cards, iced onto cakes or etched on commemorative glasses but it didn't mean squat to me until then. So, although it was only April, we talked about having a party in the summer as a way of getting friends and family together to warm our new residence and mark my birthday. My dad ferried me around so that I could pick up groceries and cheap garden furniture, but getting the house and yard ready and preparing food for around 40 people, was down to me, so it was exhausting, but thoroughly enjoyable, so much so, that I've done it every year, since.

Yesterday was the fifth one, and it was another fabulous day, with a few new faces...and  some absent ones. Most notably, my brother-in-law stayed away. My old laughing buddy, the mutual pisstaker and all around bad-influence, only put in an appearance to relieve my sister of the children, so that she could meet a group of girls for a night out on the town. He didn't even stay for a drink. I know that change is inevitable and I know that some changes bring about positive things but I don't have to like it. I know that I should (and believe me, I really, REALLY do) feel bad for my sister, who is losing a husband, but I am losing contact with an old and very dear friend. Hopefully, the awkwardness will pass but I suspect that when the dust settles and he's with someone else, he won't be a part of my life any more. That's all I will say about that.

The sun shone for most of the day and everyone tucked into the food and caught up with each others' lives until the skies opened, at which time we all gathered under the huge, borrowed gazebo and marveled at the downpour. Folks with young kids departed at around nine, exhausted little mites over their shoulders, but some lingered and we sat around the dining table until late, eating gumbo and reminiscing. We talked about another dearly departed - our friend Mike's dad, Cliff, who managed to touch so many lives, despite being, as Mike put it, "a man who just sat in the living room, chumbling his pipe." It's true. At his funeral, the introduction to his eulegy was, "Cliff Dykins - a quiet man who was heard by everybody." Everyone around the table had a different story to tell about him; little snapshots of the special relationship they'd had with him, the quiet interactions they'd shared, and it felt so good to be enjoying the same humour and camaradarie we'd shared around the Dykins table all those years ago.

Everyone wished me a happy birthday, but the event has come to mean so much more than that to me, because I really couldn't give a fig that it's my birthday. On that one Saturday in July, I celebrate much, much more than that.

Being in the recruitment business, it's important to keep up-to-date with changes in legislation and, being on the board of a fair employment committee, it's doubly important to ensure that employers are adhering to policies which are designed to prevent discrimination on the grounds of race or ethnic origin, religion, gender or sexual orientation and now, age.

From October, 2006, employers in the UK can no longer discriminate against employees on the grounds of their age - or at least we've been given that very strong impression.

The retirement age for men and women was aligned a few years ago and from October last year, all questions relating to age/date of birth have been removed from company application forms. Indeed, we are being told that any employer who delves too deeply into someone's work history or periods of education, is on a very sticky wicket, because it can be deemed to be an indirect way of trying to narrow down the age of the applicant. 

Hundreds of establishments now display their equality and diversity awards in their public reception areas, like Oscars and Grammies, giving them pride of place in polished display cabinets and indeed, our government has patted itself on its well-spun back for its achievements in the prevention of discrimination and it has won them many votes, no doubt.

I was very shocked, then, to discover that an old friend of mine was compulsorily retired on her 65th birthday at the end of December. Apparently, it's perfectly legal because a clause exists, which employers can adopt if they wish to retire their staff as a matter of company policy at age 65, provided they consult with the staff concerned so that each case can be considered, individually.

My friend received her letter a year ago, notifying her that her employer recognized the approach of her 65th birthday and inviting her to attend a series of discussions with regard to the continuation of her employment following that milestone. She spent that entire year producing evidence so support that continuation and participated in those meetings, under the impression that she would receive fair consideration, and given the importance of her role and her excellent track record in it, she anticipated continuing her employment. She was crestfallen, then, when she was given a month's notice by her employer, stating company policy to compulsorily retire staff at age 65 as the reason.

Why then did they allow her to spend a whole year with totally false hope?

Why does this clause exist and why is it that few people know about it?

Why are the companies and colleges who choose to adopt this clause being allowed to keep their equality and diversity awards and why are they being allowed to adorn their publicity material with the phrase, "we are an equal opportunities employer?"

There are, as yet, no case studies relating to the Age Discrimination Act in the UK, because the legislation is so new, but given my good friend's activist nature, and the fact that I have some very good contacts in the field, this particular one might feature very soon.

On the twelfth day of Christmas, judegunn sent to me...
Twelve lakes drumming
Eleven horses piping
Ten cats a-leaping
Nine legolas dancing
Eight trees a-milking
Seven dogs a-laughing
Six movies a-cooking
Five cre-e-e-eam roses
Four wood anemones
Three freshly-laundered sheets
Two shaven heads
...and an aragorn in a mesoterica.
Get your own Twelve Days:

I suppose I could have prepared a backdated entry but my brain is still too fudged to construct anything clever or even coherent. However, if I don't record at least something here, then I'll never get around to doing it and that would be a pity because Saturday meant so much to me and to those who are close to me.

Seventeen years since we went our separate ways, musically. Seventeen years in which there have been marriages,relocations, babies born, divorces and deaths, but after just six rehearsals in as many months, we struck up our first chord on Saturday night to a crowd of people with their hands in the air and it felt so good I couldn't stop smiling. Even through the impossibly dry mouth of the first number, my cheeks ached, looking at the hundred or so smiling faces of our oldest friends and of family members.

The ripples of applause acknowledging recognition of the songs during each intro had each band member exchanging smiles and there were one or two glassy-eyed moments during the more rousing tracks and after the set, it took each of us the best part of half an hour to reach the bar because of all the hugs and congratulations we received on route.

My son was in the audience, too.  It was his thirteenth birthday and the first time he'd seen his mum onstage singing with 'that' voice, but instead of being embarrassed, as some kids might be, he was smiling and proud, which just about put the cherry on top for me.

Some of those friendships were forged more than thirty years ago and running right through everything, we've had the music - to listen to, to dance to and later, to make. There could have been no better celebration of those friendships than Saturday night and I'll remember it for as long as I live.

All pics were taken with the camera on my phone and are not of the best quality, but as suggested by , here is my account of the day.... It's 6am. Do I really want to do this? I eat a healthy breakfast every morning. Pity I'm always starving again by 10.30am. Note the size of my mug of tea, Mami. Sun's coming up at the back of the house. I love mornings here. Time to get the boy up... Mornin' Dave. Mop management. Why do I bother? It's very morning, isn't it? Incidentally, he refused to let me snap any more after this. Makeup's on, the boy's gone to school and there's just enough time for another cuppa. Money, keys, music. All set. It's a beautiful day. On my way. Horses are waiting. I say hello to them every day. If the bus doesn't arrive on time, I'll be dead meat. Hail to the bus driver man! He's on time and this one ALWAYS puts the pedal to the metal. I enjoy the journey to work, especially when the sun is shining. Pity my camera can't capture what my eyes can see up on the M60 flyover. Listening to "Blurry, Puddle of Mud" on this leg of the ride. OK, I've arrived but my own pic of The Trafford Centre's exterior didn't work out so I cheated and stole one. This is my route into the complex, though. I've arrived and the team are all set. It's all hands to the pumps, now. Very blurry pics of the stands but the punters are coming through the door. And so it begins. We've all given up our desks so that the advisors can do their bit. There's Andrew in my seat doing his transport thing. Registrations, applications. Just a couple of satisfied clients....Actually, it's Eamonn and Aimee, who kept me supplied with bottled water and biccies. Love 'em. I'm out of here and my beloved bro-in-law is giving me a ride home. The cheeky two-fingered salute is because he's deliberately turning the car around so that I can't get the sunset. Cheers, Dave. There's that sunset. Another reason to be cheerful. We get back home and there's a power-out. Totally knackered and ready for bed. Out of it. My bed is beckoning me. No, you're not getting another pic of me in bed. Goodnight :)

I hadn't intended on taking this walk by myself but I'm glad I was alone. It was great to linger and gaze at all the beautiful treasures of late summer, to close my eyes and absorb the sounds and scents of the surroundings, and it was lovely to sit and chat with a total stranger for half an hour, to savour a pint of beer with the 86 year-old gent who was taking a bit of respite from caring for his wife who was confined to the house due to arthritis and parkinsons disease. We didn't even tell each other our names, but that didn't matter. The pics were taken with the camera on my phone and aren't of the best quality but I thought you might like to see what I saw. Plantation Bridge Narrow Boat Elf Territory Toward Redrock Golden Elder

On the way back from getting groceries today, a young woman sat on the bus with her baby and her little girl, who was maybe four years old - cute, pretty, and with an endearing little smile, which she gave me as I looked up and caught her eye, quite by accident.

An elderly gentleman got on, shopping bag and walking-stick in hand, and although he was clearly unsteady on his feet, clung to the handrail in order to engage the little girl in conversation, ask her name, etc. Both mother and child were polite, but their caution was apparent, and understandable, as this was a complete stranger.

Said old gent, instead of parking his unstable backside on the nearest seat, wended his wobbly way down the aisle, even though the bus was moving, and very carefully turned sideways, rubbed his front along my shoulder and elbow, then took a seat directly in the little girl's line of vision, at which point, the bus was queued at a junction.

"Mum. Send her down here now that the bus has stopped!"

Naturally, mum wouldn't oblige. "I've taught her that she must never climb down from the seat until we're ready to get off."

Gent produces sweet. "Tell her to come and get this."

OK, this could have been a completely innocent and genuine friendly gesture, but by now, the young mum's face was scarlet and the little girl's expression made it obvious that she felt she was on the spot. "No thank you," her tiny little voice said.

"Ey! I've raised four girls, you know? -YOU- come and get it and give it to her."

By this time, I was rolling my eyes, fast reforming my opinion. This was not an old gent but a silly old fart.

"That's okay. Thank you very much, but I don't want her to have the sweet. It's bad for her teeth, anyway." The mother's voice was becoming tremulous and I was trying to think of something tactful to say, which might just get silly old fart to let it drop.

"Well, if you take that attitude, the bloody kids aren't going to eat -ANYTHING-. I've brought four daughter's up."

I was biting my lip. Thought bubble, reading..."yeah, and it's possible you abused every one of them." Sometimes I'm pleased that people can't tell what I'm really thinking. The poor young woman had to spend the rest of her journey trying to avoid eye-contact with the bloke and she was very subdued when she alighted with her family. 

Is it a sign of our times that the simple act of talking to a child or offering a sweet is greeted with protective/defensive behaviour? Was this just a stubborn old man, determined to have his way or have we simply become aware and wise to potential predators?

Have I become so twitchy and suspicious in my old age that I have to question everything?

I know I gave up on the game of football many years ago and have been generally disillusioned with the whole culture, but I watched the second half of the England v Portugal game this afternoon and the ensuing extra time, enjoying the excitement and the atmosphere generated by the crowd.

Yep, I'm gutted that we're out of the world cup and my heart went out to the players weeping on the pitch. It was good to see some genuine and sympathetic comisserations from members of the Portugeise squad, which made me realize how much nicer the personalities seem to be, nowadays.

Perhaps I won't be so scathing about the institution in future.

People see you as "different", but in a very interesting and alluring way. You are peaceful by nature, but can get very dangerous when you feel an injustice has happened... especially to animals. People like you are rare, diamonds in the rough.

You scored 67% kindness, 52% courage, 10% seedy past, and 38% secretiveness!

"I know you made a promise. I'm letting you off the hook. Let me go, Jack."


You are Boone. You are kind and brave, with a slightly less checkered past than your fellow survivors. You are an open book, and do not keep secrets from anyone. While your humanitarian efforts are chivalrous, being so trusting and helpful can get you into major trouble...especially when you spend your days hanging around John Locke. Classy, stylish, and eloquent. You've got a way about you that floors everyone you meet.
What's Your Funky Inner Hair Color?

My baby started high school today. He went off in his crisp, new uniform, shiny shoes and a new bag with his supplies in it...and the bus went flying by, a full eight minutes early, so our rehearsed journey and the comfort zone went right out the window.

So I had to put him on a different bus and send him on an unfamiliar route. He was so lost and miserable that he didn't even wave.

All part of him growing, I know, but it sucks.

Yesterday, something happened, which in itself was terrible and quite possibly tragic, which makes me feel guilty for turning it in on myself and getting upset about how it makes me feel so I'm going to purge myself in here and hope that I can feel more constructive afterwards.

I was in the back seat of my friend's car, sitting with my 11 year old and her 8 year old. Her husband was driving and we were just off down the motorway to take the kids to visit a farm for a couple of hours. We were chit-chatting amongst ourselves and my eyes were fixed on the road ahead between the two heads in the front, admiring the countryside as is my wont. For a moment, I was frozen, dumbstruck by the surreal image of flying earth, grass, twigs and metal, all being churned by a rolling vehicle that became airborne just as I managed to point.

Paul slowed down and the car continued to tipple and tumble, landing again and continuing to roll until it finally came to a standstill on the opposite carriageway. With four lanes of traffic between us, we could not access the vehicle, but a truck driver stopped and ran to the scene and so I proceeded to alert the emergency services - ambluance, police and fire crew, in that order.

Now, I am not one to panic in a crisis - ever, but in that slo-mo moment, I was trying to consider whether that vehicle was going to burst into flames and what that truck-driver was going to pull out of the chewed-up car...and if the two kids sitting next to me would see it. Both were already struck dumb by what they could see and the youngest was ashen. Mine just fixed his eyes on me and watched, agape, whilst I gave information and directions in triplicate, my escalating anxiety evident in my voice as I dealt with the ambulance operator, because she insisted that I give direction in terms of north, south, east and west, when I didn't have a bloody clue. 

I said the words as two children were removed from the car by the truck driver and, thank God the Almighty, they stood upright, just rubbing their eyes and their bruises. The driver scrambled out, bleeding and he ran around to the passenger side, but the passenger didn't get out. I just hope they're okay.

The police operator was nothing short of fantastic, got me calm again and took more details - mine, then handed me back to control so I could deal with the fire crew, but by then, I think I'd gone onto automatic pilot because I don't even remember talking to them. The kids began to get upset and we just had to talk them down, point out that the children were okay and that it was probably due to the fact that they were wearing their seatbelts...but this made me feel sick because I'd only been able to buckle-up five minutes earlier, due to a shuffle of passengers between the two cars in our little convoy. David reached over and squeezed my hand and the look on his face was enough to tell me that he was thinking the same thing that I was.

We remained on the scene long enough to guide the emergency vehicles in and then had to move because our presence on the opposite carriageway would only encourage rubbernecking and possible cause another accident. I could have done with going home, but it was a day out for the kids and certainly, the two in our car needed to have their minds taken off what they'd just seen.

Thing is, I came unraveled, bit by bit and finally, passed out on the journey home and then I was fit for nothing for the rest of the day, feeling like a total wuss. The more I think about it, though, the more I know why I feel so badly - because I couldn't be there. Right or wrong, my natural instinct is to want to touch and comfort someone in trouble or in fear. I have no medical training but I know that I can calm people and that's what I always want to do, but we couldn't get to them.

A long time ago, a beloved friend of mine was in trouble - right the way across the atlantic, and I had to do the same thing, then - deal with the US emergency services and get them to her. I helped her, yes, but I couldn't be there to hold her hand while she cried and it was so, so hard.

I'm not even sure what that says about me as a person, because I can't stand it when other people take a situation and make it all about how it affects THEM. Maybe I just don't like to feel helpless, and would rather act - do ANYTHING rather than nothing - because it makes me feel better ::shudders::

Yes. I think we're going to be very happy here. The house is warm and comfortable, especially now that walls have been painted, beds and other flatpack furniture built and all the miscelaneous stuff has been put away.

The whole deal took much longer than anticipated and, because of the illness and sad passing of my grandmother, had to be done in stages and without the help of most of 'the team', whose energies were required elsewhere.

The littlun loves his bed, his room, and the woods out back where he can play with his school buddies, I have a room and a bed which haven't been shared with anyone and ...FINALLY...I have internet access. Oh joy of joys.

Only damper on the matter? Nana didn't get to see it. Oh well, we'll have to enjoy the house for her, too. Rest in peace, sweetheart. Thank you for teaching me to knit and to make houses from cardboard boxes, dolls from wool. Thank you for the gift of time when you really didn't have any. God bless.

OK. I'm fine. The old house has been left behind and the youngun and I are settled enough back in my old hometown. The journey to work is a pain in the arse but I won't have to rely upon public transport forever, so there's light at the end of that particular tunel. David is comfortable at school and is enjoying regular contact with people once his school day has ended - something he didn't have the benefit of at the other place.

The only bugbear has been the lack of internet access, which has pissed me off and pissed others off. I simply could not find a provider who would give me a service here unless I signed up for a 12 month, non-transferable contract but then when I relented and decided to commit, there were other complications so there you go.

At least now I've found a house. It will probably take a few weeks for the solicitors and the bank to sort it all out but I can just about wait that long. Actually this house was worth the wait because it is exactly what we were looking for and the atmosphere in there is lovely so...we're happy.

Christmas was lovely but then I got sick with some gut virus, which didn't go away until the weekend...hence I'm about 10 pounds lighter, which isn't entirely a bad thing. Not a recommended way to lose weight, though, especially as my symptoms were exacerbated by the antics of some moron who totally ruined the pleasant memories of a handful of dates.

I had the pleasure of this eejit's company for no more than five dates - delightful ones for the best part, but then he asked me to move in with him (!?!?!?). Of course ,my answer was a resounding 'no' but he would have none of it, wanted an explanation, debunked my reasoning then proceeded to offend a group of my friends by getting drunk and trying to exit the moving vehicle driven by my best friend's mother.

Naturally, I had no intention of seeing him again but since then, I have been bombarded with text messages and voicemails ranging from tearfully remorseful and apologetic to accusational. In short, he is a git.

I shall admit to being shaken up by the incident but at least I stood my ground and kept my feelings of intimidation hidden whilst I dealt him a right royal tongue-lashing. It felt like deja vu. I saw ten years' worth of an abusive relationship flashing before my eyes as he stood there and demanded that I explain myself so thank God for that past because it gave me the nouse and the strength to square up and say 'fuck you.'

I should like to thank him for reminding me that I really like being single.

I had reason to thank a very dear online friend yesterday for giving me a 'perspective check' whilst I was mid-rant about my ex's wife hijacking my life. 

It's been almost three and a half years since the split and he's been married for a year and a half, so acceptance has well and truly set in with only one or two minor slips on my part, triggered by the occasional display of insensitivity by the ex and his missis...and today something happened - a test? An opportunity to show my mettle? Strange that it should happen after my first lapse in a while, but then life is extremely strange.

I called him to say that our boy probably wouldn't go to see him today because he was looking and feeling rough. He sounded very subdued and I could hear his wife crying in the background. He'd come home from work because their cat had been found dead in next door's garden. Now they were faced with the problem of what to do with poor old Curly, since their yard is concreted and there was no suitable place to bury him.

I invited them both over here with the poor creature so that they could bury him in my garden alongside my two departed and much-loved cats. It is the first time she has set foot in my home since the shit hit the fan, so this was something big for all of us, but the gesture was appreciated and they were both relieved and grateful.

The two of them, along with my son, held a little funeral, shed a few tears, and I made cups of tea for them in the kitchen and....I am glad that I did it, not just because it was probably the right and compassionate thing to do but because it restored something in me and gave me another perspective check.

I will be leaving this home, shortly, you see, and they will be moving into it - another reason for my recent sleeplessness and melancholy. After all, her moving in here will mean that she is going to well and truly occupy my space and have the life that I wanted, but when I saw her standing there in my kitchen, I realized that I don't want that life any more.

Strange symbolism at play; burying a beautiful ginger cat and my old dreams along with it.

I couldn't access this thing, yesterday, being away from my computer for most of it, but it was a strange day and shades of it have echoed throughout today as well.

I knew I would have to go and visit my family back at the home town, even though I was really too physically drained to do it, but it had been weeks since my last visit and my grandmother 'worries about us.' 

I've been bone-weary for days, because we've been short-handed at work and it's been a balancing act trying to fit the extra duties into my working day. I could have done without having to make a presentation on Thursday to an audience of peers from all around the north west. Sure, it went well and I wasn't intimidated by the large group of people because, as usual, my alter-ego kicks in and nobody gets to see the shy wreck that I am on the inside. Problem is, once the alter-ego steps back into the shadows, I'm knackered, truly exhausted and I should probably have cancelled the family visit and recharged my batteries instead.

I should have stayed home, typed up the three reports I needed to do, cut the grass and played online, but the family beckoned and I just feel too guilty when I don't go because nana is 89, is fading and always lights up when she sees us. I also told myself that this was the right time to tell my family about my decision to pack up my life here and go back home.

It was very stupid of me to think that my mother would actually listen to my reasons for selling up and relocating - practical, financial and emotional, but, as usual, her attention was on other things.  She changed the subject so many times that I abandoned the topic in the end. She waited until I was about to leave before bombarding me with questions about my decision in a manner that only belied the fact that she hadn't listened to a word I'd said.

By the time I arrived at Nana's, I was too drained to do anything for her, except make her a cup of tea and a sandwich. She sat and chatted with her great-grandson, during which time I started to get chest pain and a sensation of unreality. The prospect of enduring public transport for the journey home filled me with dread and I just wanted to cry...so I called Jane.

We went to her house, instead, where I wouldn't have to explain anything, wouldn't have to do anything except drink tea and be cuddled while I cried. It isn't because I'm depressed or devastated or having a nervous breakdown. I'm simply daunted by the changes on the horizon and more than a bit put out by the physical indications that I'm simply not as young as I was. In short, my body is fucked.

I sat and I wept buckets in the arms of my oldest friend, who just passed me the tissues and reminded me, gently, of what a survivor I've always been and the fact that so many people are already on standby to help me relocate my life.  She listened to my accounts of how I escape on the internet with the only person in the world who understands my creative side and who enjoys it more than anyone else.  She said she doesn't blame me for doing it and is happy that it brings me so much happiness and comfort.

I drank ginger wine until I fell asleep and then this morning, woke up to the most amazing blue sky. I got dressed at 6.15am and went for a walk, past the horses and onto a trail that I hadn't walked for thirty years. It was nothing but reclaimed wasteland back then, but now, the hedgerows are mature, dripping with thick, creamy hawthorn blossom. I heard a lark but couldn't see it because the sun was so strong and I smiled, because I can't remember the last time I heard that song. I remembered it, though. I remembered lying on my back in the grass as a nine-year-old, just watching those birds soar until my eyes watered.

Jane brought us home early so that I could get on with the reports and I've only just now finished, but at least they're done. Ordinarily, I'd be looking forward to some online company but that isn't going to happen - probably not for the forseeable, which is a great pity, because that's one change that I am not yet ready for. I'm not sure I ever will be, but some things are outside our control and accepting that is the trick, I guess.

I opted for an early-morning showing, since I was attending the theatre alone and wasn't sure what kind of audience I would be joining. As it happened, the auditorium was inhabited by myself, one lone female, approximate age - 18, plus five others who were lucky if they were 15 but I wasn't going to squeal.

There were three reasons for my going to see The Calcium Kid - it's a home-grown production, I liked the idea of the spoof documentary format and, to look at Orlando Bloom.

I must say, I didn't  much like the first ten minutes, found the initial commentary and few lines of script very uncomfortable and forced, but something seemed to kick in and suddenly, I was smiling. Perhaps it had something to do with the fly-on-the-wall team capturing Orlando's character, Jimmy's early-morning bedroom...er...habits.

The character is innocent and sad, completely likeable and sympathetic in a way that Norman Wisdom's characters always were during those movies made in the sixties. In fact, the whole storyline smacked of a modern-day Wisdom movie, without the staggering and slapstick, of course, so this brought about a lovely nostalgic feeling.

Wonderfully tense, menacing and believable performance by Tamer Hassan as the thwarted boxer and a smooth delivery from Michael Lerner as the powerful US boxing promoter. Orlando Bloom's performance...well, Jimmy broke my heart so he did everything right and my GOD, the camera loves him.

Yesterday, I manufactured a thousand different reasons and pathetic excuses for cancelling plans to go out last night. The invite was to a party, which would be attended by people I had never met, who were only recent, vague acquaintances of my oldest friend, who was accompanying me. She promised me music and good conversation.

Yesterday, I bit the bullet and went forward with the mindset of having a good time and just being myself, so I went out wearing only my worst jeans and a pretty shirt. The only camouflage I allowed myself was my makeup and that was only to mask the bloody awful rash that won't go away. The rest was unadultarated Jude.

The house was warm, had a huge, stone fireplace with fairylights around it, candles burning all over it, a large dog stretched out on the rug and a cat bumping my hand for attention. I was in heaven.

When a guy picked up his guitar and started to strum, I recognized the song and did something I haven't done in a while - I sang with MY voice. The sound came out so easily and so clearly and all these faces turned toward me, smiling and the guitarist closed his eyes and I could have cried. For so long, this strictured, laboured sound has been coming out of me and I feared that my singing voice was gone for ever. Silly as this may sound to some, this has been a source of my grief. I have been in mourning for my voice and was afraid to speak its name.

When the song ended, even the guitarist applauded and I was reminded again of why I like living so much. Singing like that felt so good, knowing that I brought a smile to those people's faces felt so good and...I don't feel afraid any more.

Thanks to 'Fuzz' on the guitar and to Jim on percussion for the look on your faces. Hope we meet again soon.

Title: Thorn
Author: Gunn
Rating: NC-17
Fandom: Starwars TPM
Pairing: Maul/OFC
Warning: Explicit sex. This contains a rape sequence which may shock or disturb but this was not penned for entertainment value, rather it was an exploration into the character.
Summary: Maul is instructed to take a bride.
Disclaimer: Mr Lucas, Maul belongs to you and your associates and I thank you for the inspiration. However, this is a labour of love and not a venture in remuneration.



I had the dream again last night.  The girl was the same; her touch was the same. Always, the same... the sensations engulf me.  I cannot control them.  Such ecstasy; such joy; such a delicious explosion in my loins - but no control.

Her hand slips beneath my robe and her coolness meets my hot skin; then my resolve is lost.  I awaken, bathed in sweat: seed, soaking the sheets...and I am afraid.

What good is my training, now?  I am a warrior, nearing the end of my apprenticeship.  I have the dark force at my fingertips, my body for a weapon. I can control pain - my own and that of others.  I instill fear and can master it, but not this.

My master will sanctify my union with a woman today.  He has decreed it; has chosen her for me, but I have no need of, nor do I want a wife.  However, my Lord Sidious knows what is best for me and for our order.  I wonder what she looks like. No matter.

I will have to consummate this union, today.  It will be the first time I have touched, or been touched by a woman.  I am afraid.  It is absurd, but I am afraid.  My mouth dries at the prospect of failing in my master's eyes, but he has taught me nothing; has told me, nothing.  How can I complete the act if I release at the merest touch?  Lord Sidious will not be pleased.

Will she lie still and permit me to touch her or should I be driven to use force? Shall I recline and let her take me? My master has told me nothing.  I have watched beasts in the wilderness: rutting beasts, snorting and snarling.  I have seen whores in the taverns - their hands moving over their clients, legs clasped around their waists as they fuck them against the walls.  Where is the dignity; the ritual in that? What need have I of a wife?

I bathe and dress in readiness but I am unable to eat for my stomach is knotted with the anticipation of battle, though the prospect of today's proceedings is less appealing.  I drink to moisten my lips and set out to meet my master at the appointed place.

The stone room is appropriately darkened and is adorned with our few revered icons of the Sith.  My master's words soothe me and I become calm.  I smell the cold, stone floor and feel the dampness of the air: hear the evenness of my master's measured breaths.  I feel strong again - at one with the darkness.

The woman enters, at my master's command and at once, I taste her fear.  Already, my appetite is whetted.  Through my hood, I observe her approach on weakened legs.  She shakes, visibly and is chilled by my master's very presence.  I see there is much I have to learn from him yet.

She stands before me and I hear her sticky mouth as she struggles to swallow.  She is small.  Why did I fear her?  She is physically weak; sick from fear yet I am ecstatic with it.  I remove my hood and watch the final remnants of her courage crumble to dust. I sieze her arm lest she should collapse to her knees, and I feel the small heart pounding within her breast.  She knows that I hold the power of life and death over her.  The thrill of her knowing courses through me, but I must concentrate on my master's words.  They reach me; touch me; elate me.

I repeat the ancient mantra and the power of the darkside is mine.  It feeds me as I put the mark of the Sith upon her and celebrate her pain.  Her fingers are marked with the red and the black.  Her eyes accuse me. Her mind hates me.  Her body loathes me.

My eyes devour her form.  Her skin is flawless and her abundant hair tumbles about her face.  I don't know if this is a beautiful face. What do I know of beauty? All I know is that I ache to take her.  My cock strains against the holster which would protect me in combat.  If I touch her, will I succumb at once as I did in sleep?  Will my master be angry?

Lord Sidious orders me to take her.  My heartbeat matches hers.  I turn to my master but he is leaving.  The ritual of consecration is over and I must make her mine. 

Her tears are dripping into the grime but I feel no pity; no mercy; only hunger.  With a gesture from my hand, the force catches her and sends her to the floor, but her scream only serves to fuel my resolve. I demonstrate the power of the darkside by summoning the stone table which served as our altar.  It can now be her rack; her support.

I haul her upon it and she quivers with anticipation as I tower over her.  I notice, again, how small she is and wonder how much pain I will give her, but she looks up at my face and she knows. She knows that she is my first. The fury rises within me.  Bitch! I strike her face and hold  her gaze away from me.  I will not have this woman's eyes upon me.

Being inside her is a relief.  My ardour is intact.  I have not weakened.  She is slick, but tight and I can do nothing save to follow my instincts.  I am the rutting beast who sires his brood in the wilderness; snarling and hissing.  Indeed, there is no ritual; no dignity.  It is little wonder my master chose to leave.

However...it feels warm and joyous to be fucking her.  She is lost to me as I near my release.  Her pain is the merest glimmer in the depths of my ecstasy.  I will not cry out - though I long to howl; to rage against this sensation.  it is too far removed from pain to be of any consequence.  A useless, delicious spasm.

She lays on the floor, crumpled and trembling, but she is relieved to be apart from me.  She is mine.  She knows she is mine and she is desolate.

I, however, am celebrating a victory - over my fear; over myself.

END

Darth Maul

Taylor Reese!
